title: Teaching
text:
This bachelor course introduces core statistical concepts and methods used to summarize data, analyze relationships between variables, and draw conclusions about broader populations. Emphasis is placed on best practice approaches and data interpretation.
Link to the course

title: Teaching
text:
Survival data analysis (PhD course)





This PhD course explores the analysis of survival times—the duration between a defined start and end event, such as time from diagnosis to recovery. Applications include clinical and epidemiological studies where interest lies in comparing treatment effects, assessing prognostic factors, and handling incomplete data due to censoring. Emphasis is placed on statistical methods designed to accurately analyze and interpret time-to-event data.
Link to the course

title: Teaching
section: Measuring error without error, PhD course
text:
Measuring error without error, PhD course





This course aims to equip researchers with the statistical knowledge necessary to plan and perform reliability, agreement and validity studies of measurement instruments providing quantitative or qualitative information.
Link to the course

title: Can quantum-mechanical description of physical reality be considered complete?
text:
Abstract
In a complete theory there is an element corresponding to each element of reality. A sufficient condition for the reality of a physical quantity is the possibility of predicting it with certainty, without disturbing the system. In quantum mechanics in the case of two physical quantities described by non-commuting operators, the knowledge of one precludes the knowledge of the other. Then either (1) the description of reality given by the wave function in quantum mechanics is not complete or (2) these two quantities cannot have simultaneous reality. Consideration of the problem of making predictions concerning a system on the basis of measurements made on another system that had previously interacted with it leads to the result that if (1) is false then (2) is also false. One is thus led to conclude that the description of reality as given by a wave function is not complete.

title: Can quantum-mechanical description of physical reality be considered complete?

I’m a associate professor in the department of Methodology and Statistics at Maastricht University.
I develop expertise in reliability and agreement studies since my master thesis! I think that measurement error is a very important issue that is too often neglected. Besides developing new statistical techniques for agreement and reliability studies with complex study designs, I also want to render the best practices accessible to all researchers by writing tutorials or this website, for example.



2020-now Associate professor (Maastricht University, The Netherlands)
2010-2020 Assistant professor (Maastricht University, The Netherlands)
2009-2010 Working lecturer (Mathemtatics, Liège University, Belgium)
2003-2009 Research assistant (Public Health, Liège University, Belgium)

title: Publications
text:
Selected Work

Good practices
Vanbelle S., Engelhart C. & Blix E. (2024) A comprehensive guide to study the agreement and reliability of multi-observer ordinal data. BMC Medical Research and Methodology 24, 310 open access, shiny app and R package   



 
Houtvast D.C.J., Betz M.W., Van Hooren B., Vanbelle S., Verdijk L.B., van Loon L.J.C. (2024), Underpowered Studies in Muscle Metabolism Research: Determinants and Considerations, Clinical Nutrition ESPEN, 64, 334-343 open access   



 
Vanbelle S. (2024) Statistical inference for agreement between multiple raters on a binary scale, British Journal of Mathematical and Statistical Psychology, 77 (2), 245-260 open access, shiny app and R package  



 
Mondal D., Vanbelle S., Cassese A., Candel M. (2023) Review of sample size determination methods for the intraclass correlation coefficient in the one-way ANOVA model, Statistical Methods in Medical Research, 33(3), 532-553 open access, shiny app and R package  



 


New methods
Lin T-Y, Tuerlincks F., Vanbelle S. Reliability for multilevel data: A correlation approach, Psychological Methods, in press
Vanbelle S. (2019) On the asymptotic variability of (multilevel) multirater kappa coefficients, Statistical Methods in Medical Research. 28 (10-11), 3012-3026 open access  



 
Vanbelle S. and Lesaffre E. (2018) Modeling agreement on bounded scales. Statistical Methods in Medical Research, 27 (11), 3460-3477 open access   



 
Vanbelle, S. (2017), Comparing dependent kappa coefficients obtained on multilevel data. Biom. J., 59: 1016-1034. https://doi.org/10.1002/bimj.201600093  



 
Vanbelle S. A New Interpretation of the Weighted Kappa Coefficients. Psychometrika. 2016;81(2):399-410. doi:10.1007/s11336-014-9439-4
